I.   INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2002 Country Programming Mission of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
the Government of Indonesia requested technical assistance (TA) to assist the Ministry of 
Finance (MOF) in (i) strengthening central and local public sector financial management, (ii) 
implementing a new onlending mechanism; and (iii) establishing a prudent, comprehensive, and 
efficient  local  government  financial  information  system.  The  TA  was  included  in  2003  TA 
Program to Indonesia under the Country Strategy and Program. The Fact-Finding Mission, 
fielded  during  10-13  March  2003,  reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the 
purpose  and  output,  methodology  and  key  activities,  cost  estimates,  and  implementation 
arrangements of the TA.1  
 
II.   ISSUES 
2.  Rapid implementation of decentralization has proceeded remarkably smoothly although 
it  has  created  a  number  of  gaps  and  inconsistencies  in  both  the  policy  framework  and 
implementation, particularly in intergovernmental fiscal relations. One specific area that requires 
further attention pertains to local government borrowing, as several policy and implementation 
issues need to be resolved. They include (i) clarification of the legal framework and introduction 
of safeguards in case of default; (ii) options for resolving loan arrears under the previous 
onlending system; (iii) introduction of internationally accepted accounting standards and sound 
financial management at central and local government levels; and (iv) availability of timely, 
accurate, and sufficient financial information on local governments. The reforms will support the 
development of a regional credit market in the long -term, while facilitating the flow of external 
funds to local development in the short term. 
 
3.  The current legal framework for local government borrowing is unclear and incomplete. 
Laws 22 and 25 of 1999 supported by Government Regulation 107 of 2000 in principle provide 
more latitude than in the past for regional2 borrowing from domestic and foreign sources.3  
Responsibility for borrowing is placed in the hands of the local government, including the 
decision  on  the  sources  and  currency  of  funds.  Foreign  borrowing  is  allowed,  with  the 
permission of the central Government, but without its guarantee. However, Regulation 107 also 
outlines the appropriate sources and types of regional government borrowing, the purposes to 
which borrowing may be put, and restricts borrowing through maximum debt-to-revenue ratios. 
The Law on State Finances (17/2003) introduced further requirements for regional borrowing by 
specifying regional deficit and debt limits. These limits, however, if added to national limits 
allows a total general government deficit of 9% of GDP.4 Should regions choose to borrow 
heavily utilizing these limits, given that regional revenues are expected to continue to grow, debt 
management  could  emerge  as  a  major  issue  in  macroeconomic  management.  Present 
weaknesses in financial management and information constrain the ability of MOF to effectively 
monitor and manage this risk. A ministerial decree enacted in 2001 and still in force prohibits 
regional foreign borrowing except through the central Government, but this safeguard is only an 
interim measure.  
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities in October 2002. 
2  In the Indonesian context, regional refers to provinces, districts, and cities.

4.  A crucial aspect of the borrowing framework is rules and procedures in the event of 
default. The law places responsibility with local governments, and in strict interpretation allows 
local governments to interact directly with the lender, yet does not provide for safeguards in 
case of default. Provision is made for the intercept of the general allocation grant provided to 
regional government in case of default on repayments to the central Government. It is not clear, 
however, that this intercept applies in the case of commercial lending. Even with the intercept, 
given the significant variations in debt service capacity of regions, this provision appears to be 
inadequate, particularly if more than one region is in default at any one time. Clear rules and 
procedures need to be established as to what collateral regional governments can pledge, 
procedures to be followed in the event of default, provisions for central Government intervention 
in this event, and prescribed sanctions for defaulters. 
 
5.  This is particularly important in establishing the groundwork for a regional credit market, 
given the poor past experience with regional borrowing. Until the end of 2002, multilateral as 
well as central Government lending to local governments was channeled through the regional 
development accounts (RDA), with domestic sourced funds known as RPD and foreign sourced 
funds onlent in subsidiary loan agreements (SLAs).5 Conceived as a revolving fund, the RDA 
was intended to consolidate external and domestic funds into a single source, offering standard 
terms to local governments. However, the performance of the RDA has been unsatisfactory, 
with at least 70% of loans in arrears.6 About two thirds of loan disbursements (Rp3,338 billion) 
have been to local government owned enterprises (BUMD) for a total of 397 loans, while the 
remaining amount (Rp 1,776 billion) went to local governments for a total of 362 loans.7 Water 
enterprises (PDAMs) have represented most of the BUMD borrowing, with a small residual for 
services  such  as  solid  waste  collection  and  disposal.  The  underlying  reasons  for  these 
arrears—including  fiscal  capacities,  governance,  and  administrative  issues—require  further 
investigation and analysis to inform implementation of an effective new onlending mechanism.  
 
6.  Law 25/1999 and the implementing regulations did not contain detailed provisions for 
onlending  of  foreign  loans,  which  caused  some  difficulties  for  the  processing  and 
implementation of donor-funded development projects at local level. Ministry of Finance Decree 
35/2003 addressed this problem by providing for an interim onlending mechanism to channel 
funding from international financial institutions to viable local government development projects. 
Although the decree has laid down conditions for onlending, several issues need to be resolved 
before it can be a prudent and effective conduit. For example, further clarifications are needed 
as to how the costs of borrowing, including foreign exchange risk, will be shared between 
central and local government. The legal framework remains ambiguous as to how revenue 
generating projects are to be defined or how funds will flow for projects that have both revenue 
generating  and  non-revenue  generating  components.  For  non-revenue  generating  projects 
where loan proceeds are passed on as grants, the principle of cost sharing has been adopted, 
but  the  classification  of  regional  governments  according  to  fiscal  capacity  has  not  been 
completed. Further analysis at the policy level will assist the Government both in implementing 
Decree  35  as  an  interim  solution  and  in  devising  longer  term  mechanisms  for  regional 
government  borrowing.  At  a  more  technical  level,  the  Decree  requires  that  regional 
governments applying for a new loan must have no existing RDA arrears, or must fully pay all 
arrears and indicate such willingness in their budgets. Furthermore, those in arrears will have to

(MOU) with MOF. The MOU will commit the regional government to take full responsibility for 
past  loans  and  will  document  any  restructuring  arrangements  for  arrears,  including  the 
application of an intercept mechanism as provided by law. However, no restructuring agreement 
will entail any debt write-offs. Assistance will be needed at both central and local level to 
implement the provisions on existing arrears. 
 
7.  A key element of the local government fiscal framework that is critical in facilitating 
sound  intergovernmental  fiscal  relations  and  effective  local  borrowing  is  that  of  financial 
management  and  accountability.  At  the  central  level,  the  Government  has  embarked  on 
comprehensive reforms to modernize financial management. In August 1998, the Financial 
Management Reform Committee (KPMK)8 was appointed to draft relevant new legislation and 
reform strategies. In September 2000, the Government introduced in Parliament three new laws 
on state finances, state treasury, and audit of state finances–accountability. The three laws 
contain general principles on government budgetary processes and financial management, and 
serve as a legal framework for reforms in public expenditure management. In July 2002, KPMK 
published  a  white  paper  entitled  Reform  of  the  Public  Financial  Management  System  in 
Indonesia: Principles and Strategy. In March 2003, the first of the three laws, the State Finance 
Law,  was  passed  by  Parliament.  Decentralization  added  a  new  dimension  to  financial 
management reform in the form of 3789 semiautonomous regional governments, which are 
generally inexperienced in financial management and reporting, yet will have to comply with the 
three new laws and new accounting standards. Local governments currently prepare simple 
cash-based  financial  reports,  which  comprise  statements  of  (i)  receipts,  (ii)  development 
expenditure, and (iii) routine expenditure. It is difficult to introduce sound governance principles 
and to assess creditworthiness because (i) cash balances are neither disclosed nor reconciled, 
(ii) financial assets and liabilities (e.g., outstanding loans) are not disclosed, and (iii) other 
assets and liabilities are not disclosed (e.g., fixed assets, employee benefits, etc).  
 
8.  Assessing and monitoring the fiscal and financial status of local government, either by 
MOF or by potential creditors, require consistently timely and accurate information. Similarly, 
local  government  managers  themselves  require  sound  financial  information  to  improve 
prioritization and resource management. Thus, it is critical that regional governments produce 
timely  financial  statements  that  comply  with  uniform,  internationally  recognized  accounting 
standards and are readily available to stakeholders. Given the growing proportion of regional to 
total government expenditure, such information is also essential for producing consolidated 
general government financial information. Uniform accounting standards for local governments 
are central to improved public sector financial management. Law 25 of 1999 and government 
regulation PP11 of 2001 give MOF the authority to develop and maintain the regional financial 
information system (SIKD) and to issue regulations that will ensure the efficient implementation 
of  the  system,  including  the  flow  into  the  system  of  timely,  relevant,  comparable, 
understandable, and reliable information. 
 
9.  Ongoing coordination with development partners is ensured through a Working Group 
on Decentralization, under the consultation process of the Consultative Group for Indonesia. 
While other partners are active in related areas such as developing accounting standards, 
treasury  systems  and  information  systems,  ADB  is  the  only  institution  directly  addressing 
onlending issues. This TA is focusing on conceptualizing framework for regional development

from ADB and other development partners. 
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.   Purpose and Output 
10.  The TA will prepare a framework for regional government financing from both domestic 
and  international  sources  and  recommend  restructuring  of  supporting  institutions.  This 
framework will help support the designing of future programs of ADB’s activities in the area of 
local government financing.10 As a result, financial management at the central and local levels 
and flows of timely financial information will improve. 
 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The first objective will be to analyze options for implementing an interim onlending 
mechanism in accordance with Kepmen 35 of 2003. The analysis will include management of 
loans in arrears, options for an equitable and fair mechanism for restructuring of arrears, and 
legal advice to MOF for the revision of Law 25 and PP 107. The second objective will be to 
design and pilot harmonized financial management practices at central and local level. A 
number of areas for further support have emerged through the development of the Corporate 
Plan11 within MOF, other central government agencies and regional governments in Indonesia. 
The  third  objective  will  be  to  facilitate  availability  of  timely,  accurate,  consistent  local 
government financial information. This component will be developed in close cooperation with 
the World Bank.  
 
12.  In order to meet the first objective, the TA will provide technical advice to support the 
implementation of a new onlending mechanism with the purpose of channeling credits from the 
International Financial Institutions (IFIs) through the Central Government to LGUs. The project 
will assist the Government in resolving loans in arrears so as to widen the number of LGUs 
eligible for new onlending operations. The new onlending mechanism will be designed to grant 
adequate loan terms and flexibly allocate foreign currency risks in line with the fiscal capacity of 
the  LGUs.  This  component  includes  advice  to  the  Government  for  reforms  of  the  legal 
framework for local government borrowing. 
 
13.  Under  the  second  objective  a  time-bound  implementation  plan  will  be  prepared  for 
improving financial management and maintaining consistency between central Government and 
local government practices. Systems will be pilot-tested in MOF as well as in a large number of 
finance departments of local governments. Four sub-projects will be tested: (i) strengthening 
organizational development and human resource capacity related to financial management; (ii) 
strengthening  economic  policy  and  fiscal  evaluation  capacity;  (iii)  strengthening  financial 
management  and  control;  and  (iv)  strengthening  accounting  and  financial  reporting  by 
implementing new government accounting standards in line with international standards. 
 
14.  In the area of financial information improvement, the TA will design a local government 
FIS that will (i) improve information regularity, timeliness, and quality; (ii) support external audits; 
(iii) shorten the data consolidation time frame and free up resources for analysis; (iv) increase

(v) integrate  with  central  Government  and  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE)  systems,  thereby 
supporting management of fiscal risks, budget preparation, and analysis. This will entail the 
development of financial reporting policies and standards, valuing local government assets and 
liabilities, developing methodologies and systems for providing consistent local government 
financial information and developing FIS for BUMDs. 
 
15.  Workshops and seminars will be held for each component to disseminate the findings 
and identify regional governments willing to participate in developing the different components.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $750,000 equivalent, comprising $335,000 in 
foreign exchange and $415,000 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested 
ADB to finance $600,000 equivalent covering the total foreign exchange cost and $265,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will provide $150,000 
equivalent to finance counterpart staff, office facilities, and other expenditures (Appendix 2).  
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA Executing Agency will be the Secretariat General of MOF. The implementing 
agencies will be the Directorate General for Central and Regional Fiscal Balance (DGCRFB), 
the Directorate General of Financial Institutions (DGFI), and the Agency for the State Finance 
and Accounting (BAKUN) of MOF. About 11 person-months of international consulting services 
(individual consultants) will be required. The international consultants will be experts in debt 
restructuring, public financial management, and financial information systems (Appendix 3). The 
international consultants will associate with domestic consultants who will provide about 42 
person-months  of  consulting  services  in  public  sector  accounting,  public  sector  financial 
management, debt restructuring, and law. ADB will engage the consultants in accordance with 
its Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for 
engaging domestic consultants. The TA will be implemented over 23 months, from December 
2003 to October 2005. 
 
IV.       THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for the Local Government Financing Project, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  This technical assistance (TA) will provide inputs to the preparation of a cluster of 
interventions beginning with a TA loan in 2003 followed by further loans in 2004 and 2005. The 
primary purpose is to assist the Government in designing a program, which will be outlined in a 
policy matrix. Each group of consultants will produce a report, which will be used as advisory 
input  for  the  subsequent  interactions.  The  reforms  will  support  the  design  of  financing 
mechanisms  for  regional  government  development  in  the  long  -term,  including  the 
implementation of an interim onlending mechanism for ODA.  
 
A.  Scope 
2.  The TA will require the services of a team of international and domestic experts in public 
sector  financial  management,  local  government  finance,  debt  restructuring,  public  sector 
governance, financial market law, accounting and auditing, and financial information systems 
(FIS). The TA will deliver contributions for RRPs and its appendixes in the following areas: (i) 
introducing  public  sector  financial  management  reform;  (ii)  formulating  a  strategy  and 
implementing it to resolve local government loans with arrears; (iii) establishing a mechanism for 
onlending loans from international financial institutions to local governments, including reform of 
the legal framework; and (iv) designing and implementing a central information system for local 
government finances. 
 
1.   Public Finance (Local Finance) Experts (international, 4 person-months; 
domestic, 15) 
 
3.  The experts will have experience in public finance, particularly in local government 
financing and intergovernmental fiscal relations. They will assist in fiscal mapping and analyzing 
local government fiscal capacities. They should have experience in local government borrowing 
systems in other countries and provide comparative analysis. The experts will review decreed 
35  to  identify  areas  requiring  clarification  or  amendment  for  effective  implementation  of 
onlending and on granting arrangements. The experts will also analyze underlying reasons for 
the accumulation of arrears, including fiscal capacities, governance, and other issues taking into 
account previous analysis produced by ADB TA and the work of other development partners.  
4.  The  experts  will  also  have  experience  in  designing  financial  and/or  management 
information  systems.  They  will  work  closely  with  the  Directorate  General  for  Central  and 
Regional Fiscal Balance (DGCRFB). The experts will design a project to implement a regional 
financial management system that will (i) improve information regularity, timeliness, and quality; 
(ii) support external audits; (iii) shorten the data consolidation time frame and free up resources 
for analysis; (iv) increase information coverage and support step-by-step move to full financial 
statements;  and  (v)  integrate  with  central  government  and  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE) 
systems, thereby supporting management of fiscal risks, budget preparation, and analysis.  
 
2.   Public Sector Debt Experts (international, 3 person-months; domestic, 6) 
 
5.  The experts will have qualifications and experience in public finance and in public sector 
debt. They should have prior experience with issues in local government borrowing issues and 
in restructuring loans in arrears. They will work closely with the Directorate for Subsidiary Loan 
Management (DSLM) in the Directorate General for Financial Institutions of the Ministry of 
Finance (MOF). The experts will undertake analysis of the regional development account (RDA) 
loan portfolio to develop recommendations and mechanisms for reducing the number of loans in

arrears to local government authorities (provinces, cities and districts). They will not consider 
loans to local government-owned enterprises (BUMD) or SOEs.  
6.  To achieve this objective, the consultants will assess: (i) portfolio and restructuring 
design,  (ii)  past  and  future  loan  processing,  (iii)  loan  portfolio  management,  and  (iv)  risk 
management and loan monitoring system. 
 
3.  Public Financial Management (international, 4 person-months; domestic, 15) 
 
7.  The experts will have experience in public sector reform, public financial management, 
accounting, and accounting standards for the public sector. They will work closely with the 
Agency for State Finance and Accounting (BAKUN) of MOF. The experts will design a program 
to  strengthen  and  harmonize  financial  management  practices  at  central  and  local  levels, 
including implementing revised accounting standards at the local level.  Since MOF has already 
designed the general outline of the program, the experts will strongly emphasize assessing the 
implementation schedule, identify risks for the reforms, and design risk scenarios and possible 
responses to keep the reforms on track.  
8.  There will be five subareas: 
 
(i)  strengthening  organizational  development  and  human  resource  management 
(HRM) in financial management; 
(ii)  strengthening economic policy and fiscal evaluation capacity; 
(iii)  strengthening financial management and control; 
(iv)  strengthening accounting and financial reporting; and 
(v)  designing a project that will develop and implement a FIS for BUMD, utilizing 
experiences gained from establishing such a system for SOEs established in the 
Ministry of State-Owned Enterprises.  
 
9.  The experts will also contribute to enhancing local government financial information by 
 
(i)  developing a detailed strategy and plan for enhancing the local government FIS, 
and identifying incentives (to encourage rapid local government adoption); 
(ii)  designing and building financial reporting schedules to collect local government 
information, allowing for a variety of implementation paths and points; 
(iii)  developing guidance and training materials and plan; and 
(iv)  developing communications materials and plan. 
 
4.  Legal Adviser  for  Reform  of  Local  Government  Legislation  (domestic,  3 
person-months) 
 
10.  The expert will advise MOF on the revisions of Law 25 and PP 107 insofar as these 
revisions affect the possibilities for future local government borrowing. The objective of the 
revisions is to have as large a spectrum for future local government borrowing as possible.  
 
B.  Workshops/Seminars 
11.  The consultants will organize workshops as required for the sole purpose of sharing their 
findings  with  government  officials.  The  workshops  will  be  attended  by  ADB  missions, 
Government officials, and consultants with the purpose of reaching agreement on the cluster of 
sector development programs.
